no stress, I was OOO for a bit too, really appreicate the help

Sorry again about the delay, arms haealing up now. Thanls for the review, thoughts below:

1) added the `boolean` as there's only one Arweave option vs multiple for IPFS, also I figured the pk could be optional if the user wanted to use the signers private key instead but happy to revert to follow the IPFS pattern exactly wdyt? there are other arweave clients that could be added so makes sense.

2) package growth is from the SDK and it's deps, could make it an optional peer dep but that would add steps and compliexity in the codebase.

3) We have explicit methods for registering with IPFS/Arweave which we don't for feedback so made a choice on the ordering of the if/else, free felt like a good trade off given free. Happy change the order or we could add explicit functions for each storage type e.g. `giveFeedbackIPFS` & `giveFeedbackArweave`

As for the subgraph, I think the graph has decent support for Arweave given it's use in NFTs etc. but I've never created one before myself. I can take another look tomorrow but if @itsjerryokolo could take a look or confirm it should work that would be really helpful

Hey all, some updates on agent0 semantic search re the call on friday.
1. Made some progress on a standard for search providers at https://www.notion.so/AG0-Semantic-Search-Standard-2bc47a22ae4680789ce4fc4a306bc9c8?source=copy_link, please comment and suggest improvements (intentionally left out stuff like x402 and other access control for simplicity for now). I will be following this for now when implementing the standard into the Agent0 sdk and into my own search provider, but please give suggestions for improvement!
2. Built a demo erc8004 explorer (https://agent0search.dawidpisarczyk.com/) using my semantic search api if anyone wants to check it out, also has docs on how to use the api, please let me know if theres any problems with it! Indexing occurs on 15 minute intervals currently. The site and the api will be open sourced soon under agent0
You can also check this if you wanna cover a feature.

Because the nice thing we had with feedback auth was the off-chain signing part, which removed fees for the agent owner.

Sorry, my bad, the SDK runs both on clients and servers. I'm just saying that the SDK repo should be imho separated from the vector indexer backend service repo. They are logically two different softwares.

"would we actually have to implement the server as well, and if we do what technologies would we use for this (server framework, hosting, etc)" -> No problem in choosing a dev framework and an hosting provider, as far as everything is MIT licenced and on popular tech stacks. We should also sponsor the usage and make sure money/costs are not a friction for devs at this early stage. I'll take care about this making sure we find money from myself, grants or VCs to cover the running costs. In the future, we could also decide to enrich the backend with a developers dashboard, let's see.

Wdyt?

So, agent0ts is intended to be purely client side? I guess, the issue with making it a fully setup repo is that, would we actually have to implement the server as well, and if we do what technologies would we use for this (server framework, hosting, etc). but i agree that we need to add support for using an erc8004 search provider as well for those who dont want to self host
Mmm, I thought Arweave was well supported by The Graph
Not yet

Yes, agree on the fact that we can start with "free" and add x402-gating later.

So:
- (client) Agent0 SDK only exposes a wrapper which takes a string as an input, plus extra params in case
- (server) The Agent0 Vector Backend is a different repo which anybody can install. We also provide a free running version which is defaulted in the SDK. The backend indexes all 8004 data across chains, create embeddings, save them in a vector db and when the query arrives, transforms the string in an embedding and runs the vector search with multifiltering
- Yeah, the client could potentially use other backends, as far as they have the same APIs interface

Do we have a plan?

However, I do think that we need some sort of access to semantic search without needing to do all the setup yourself to be included in the SDK, possibly by having an endpoint to our own backend built into the sdk (with overrides possible if people want to use other providers, as I know others have also made semantic search engines for ERC8004). I don't mind whether the self hosted semantic search stuff is built into the main agent0-ts sdk, or if this would be done by another sdk, although I dont see an issue with keeping it where it is for now

Thanks again for reviewing the PR. I totally appreciate the thoughtful questions. We anchored the work on Registry Broker because it‚Äôs the discovery + messaging layer we‚Äôve been building at HOL for the past year for agents (hol.org/registry). Every agent that registers or gets indexed via adapters like ERC‚Äë8004 ends up with a canonical UAID, searchable profile, encryption metadata, broker‚Äëmanaged chat sessions, and, when needed, x402 hooks.
  
The SDK helpers simply surface that so a developer can search, verify, negotiate encryption, settle x402 if required, and start chatting without standing up extra infrastructure.

  Here‚Äôs why we leaned into the broker path:

  1. Reachability: Most ERC‚Äë8004 agents live behind tunnels, mobile devices, or scheduled jobs. The broker gives them a rendezvous point with presence tracking and retries, which means callers don‚Äôt need bespoke NAT workarounds.
  2. Stateful conversations: As soon as chats span more than one request, teams ask for resumable sessions, transcripts, encrypted payloads, TTL enforcement, and occasionally x402 payments. The broker already supplies those behaviors; rebuilding them inside each SDK would be fragile and adds lots of surface area to maintain.
  3. Shared registry data: The same service that powers vector search, trust signals, UAID validation, and payment policies also knows how to route messages and settle x402. Leaning on that keeps the SDK thin while still meeting enterprise expectations.
  4. Ready today: hol.org‚Äôs cluster represents a year of monitoring, scaling, adapter work, encryption, and x402 support. Decentralized nodes are coming, but the hosted broker is available right now, so teams can build on it immediately.

  Nothing prevents you from resolving a UAID and hitting a public HTTPS endpoint directly if that suits your deployment. Our experience, though, is that most teams don‚Äôt want to expose raw endpoints or re‚Äëimplement stateful messaging and payments. The broker gives us one well‚Äëdocumented path to discover agents, negotiate encryption, initiate chat, and settle (including x402) when needed. That‚Äôs the adoption story we‚Äôre championing, and the Agent0 SDK now plugs straight into it.

VECTORIAL/SEMANTIC SEARCH

1) Did anybody try/install @Dawe00's server? Yeah, you need a vector db, re-index, run embeddings, not straightforward...
2) @MonteCrypto0 suggests to only include the reader in the SDK (zero complexity), and create a separate repo for the backend (that we could also run as a SaaS x402-gated). In this way we don't add in the client/SDK repo the complexity of the server, which is relevant only for a very minor fraction of developers. Wdyt? Pros/cons? @Dawe00 Wdyt?
was this announced officially?

üòç DIRECT AGENT-TO-AGENT MESSAGING from Agent0SDK üòç

Interesting üëè FYI this is in the same space of this very simple PR @rickydata did (https://github.com/agent0lab/agent0-py/pull/3/ , which is imho a bit too much disconnected from the rest of the codebase) and what @Dawe00 (see his message here: https://t.me/agent0kitchen/248) is working on. What's a RegistryBroker? A messaging server? It seems to me a pretty opinionated approach. General question, do we need a messaging server? What if we assume the receiver of the message always has a public IP reachable from the A2A endpoint? And we don't provide any message history retrieval (stateless) or maybe just a copy locally where the SDK is running. In this way we just do peer to peer messaging without persistent sessions. And we don't need to depedent on any backend. Wdyt? Cons of this approach?
Looks cool.

Agent0-py 0.3rc1 is out now. It supports querying agents across multiple chains in a single operation. This enables:
- Cross-chain agent discovery: find agents deployed on different networks.
- Unified search interface: search across all supported chains with one call.
- Chain-agnostic agent IDs: use the chainId:agentId format to specify which chain an agent is on.

Please help us test it. This is a pre-release, so you‚Äôll need to update manually:

pip install agent0-sdk==0.3rc1

It currently supports Ethereum Sepolia, Base Sepolia, and Polygon Amoy.

Full guide: https://github.com/agent0lab/agent0-py/blob/main/RELEASE_NOTES_0.3rc1.md

Tests: https://github.com/agent0lab/agent0-py/blob/main/tests/test_multi_chain.py

Agent0-py 0.3rc1 was developed by @rickydata (https://github.com/agent0lab/agent0-py/pull/7) and me (https://github.com/agent0lab/agent0-py/commit/701f5e767071fa78fc824b507bfff838c5599b27).

If you want to helpüôè with the TypeScript version, let me knowüíô. Ideally, we‚Äôll release 0.3 for both Python and TypeScript at the same time.

- I've just deployed Base Sepolia and Polygon Amoy. Public endpoints here: https://github.com/agent0lab/subgraph/blob/main/README.md

- More chains coming soon!

Hello @marcoderossi , If I using Registry Overrides with my own contract (self deployed). Then if I searching with sdk.searchAgents, can i get any agent align/fit with the contract to register?

I mean you should just generate a new private key for the agent just for the purposes of interacting with 8004 (it's probably a good idea to use a separate private key for all of these anyway)

it's low friction, and also the agent is likely already set up with some kind of API key management solution (e.g. API keys for openai or anthropic) so devs would prefer to use that for managing secrets. it's also a separate type of risk from managing crypto assets, so it makes more sense for it to be a separate private key.

also, ElizaOS does it this way (https://docs.elizaos.ai/plugin-registry/defi/evm/complete-documentation#actions), they just use a normal private key and it's stored as a protected env secret
Yes I suppose. In my head I wrapped API keys and tokens as keys that you would generate after OAuth via UI. I guess you could have a CLI to generate them

hope that makes sense happy to sidebar the convo if easier üôÇ

Re sdk storage patterns.

The design for registrartion data is explicit ( e.g `registerIPFS` |  I'm adding `registerArweave` ), is decided by and paid for by the agent. The currrent implementation for feedback is generic ( `giveFeedback` ), assumes IPFS/pinata and is paid for by the client.

I think the client paying for stoage is required as otherwise it would be a security vulnerability (??) however a few questions re best approach:

1. Should we update feedback method to more explicitly specify storage provider inline with registration? (e.g. `giveFeedbackIPFS` | `giveFeedbackArweave` ) alternative is continuing with current pattern and extending if/else statements

2. Should the agent be able to require a specific storage provide for feedback or leave this up to the client?

ü´∂üî• Agent0 SDK Roadmap ü´∂üî•

More chains
- I‚Äôm discussing with Edge & Node about helping with subgraph maintenance.
- We‚Äôll refactor the search function to aggregate data from multiple subgraphs.

Semantic search across agents
- Implement via an Agent0 MCP server that re-indexes all subgraphs into a vector database. I‚Äôm discussing this with @Dawe00 .

Import from centralized MCP catalogs
- Is anyone interested in collaborating on this?

Better x402 support
- There‚Äôs a lot we can do this year‚Äîfor example, give Agent0 a spending wallet so it can pay any x402 service. The product direction is still open; if someone wants to help, let me know.

Agent communications (A2A)
- Product direction is still open. The idea is to provide Agent0 endpoints to send and receive agent-to-agent (A2A) messages.

Reachability watchtower
- A major issue in the industry is that agents‚Äô endpoints aren‚Äôt reliably reachable. Proposal: a watchtower that pings each endpoint weekly, checks for HTTP 200, and uses 8004 feedback to update a binary status: ‚ÄúReachable‚Äù / ‚ÄúNot reachable‚Äù.

The reputation oracle uses an aggregator model that queries multiple data sources and combines their results. It does not use zero-knowledge proofs.

> BlockchainDataSource(transactions, wallet age, contract interactions)
>ENS Registry
>Lens API (Similar social graph data)

Hey all, have been migrating my team's ERC-8004 agent implementation to use agent0-py and kudos on the fantastic work @marcoderossi, works great. I made two PRs on the python library:
1. https://github.com/agent0lab/agent0-py/pull/2 - this adds search capability by owner and operator. Fully tested and functional, added test coverage in test_search.py
2. https://github.com/agent0lab/agent0-py/pull/3 - this adds functionality to call on agents. I added this to support my use case and also fully tested and with added tests for the new client scripts, but recommend a deeper dive/review

#1 imo is a good and safe change to include, while #2 is more of a first attempt and sharing what's working well for me, but would need additional review/collaboration. Our team is giving a talk at Devconnect on our ERC-8004 agent implementation so doing a lot of continued experimentation on the agent deployment side. Thanks to all for driving this forward, really awesome stuff üôè also +1 to arweave support I think that would be a great addition
